all_paragraphs: You are a predictive analytics company specialized in sales forecasting. And your client is a big grocery chain asking you to predict it’s sales quantity for the next 30 days.
Now, what information will you be looking for to deliver the forecast?
Past sales data of course. Let’s say you were given their past 2 years of sales data. So your forecasting model becomes something like this:
Now think about how confidently you can say that you’ll make a good, reasonable forecast using just this single historical dataset?

That’s of course not how it works in the real world. In real-world forecasting historical sales is just one piece of information, but you’ll also be looking for store locations, state holidays, any special events, ad spending or promotional activities etc — in fact, every bit of information that affects sales.
Each piece of this information essentially becomes a variable in your forecasting model:
future sales = f(past sales, special events, holidays, promotion……)

That is indeed where the power of multivariate forecasting comes from. The real world is interconnected and the outcome of a process is usually the result of multiple inputs and actions. So no wonder why data scientists will be looking for every piece of information relevant for building predictive models.

In this article I’ll be talking about two powerful multi-variate time series forecasting models — Vector Autoregressive (VAR) and Panel Data Models— and demonstrate their applications with code snippets in two different programming languages — Python and R.

Before defining Vector Autoregression let’s understand what’s auto-regression. As the name suggests, it’s a regression of a variable on itself, on its past values — as I just wrote in the introduction. In this case, independent variables are the past values of the same univariate data series that’s being predicted.

Vector Autoregression generalizes this univariate concept and allows for the inclusion of additional correlated variables in the model. In this case, each variable is forecasted using its own past (lag) as well as the lag values of exogenous factors.

In univariate forecasting techniques, future values are predicted as a function of past values. So, if you want to predict the population of a city in the year 2021 you take a simple univariate forecasting approach:

But if you want to make a forecast over a longer time horizon (let’s say population in 2050), we know that there are many other factors needed to be considered — birth rate, mortality, education, income, and so on. These factors are called exogenous factors or covariates. In the short-term, impacts of these exogenous factors are not so much, so we can ignore them, but in the long term their impacts compound and make a measurable difference.

VAR is such a kind of multivariate forecasting model that incorporates exogenous variables in the modeling process. In this process, the dependent variable is forecasted using its own past (lag) values as well as the lag values of exogenous factors.

To demonstrate how it works, I’m using a US macroeconomic dataset comprising of 14 different variables. It’s a quarterly dataset from 1959 all the way to 2009. For this demonstration purpose, however, I’m using just two variables: Gross Domestic Product (realgdp) and personal consumption expenditure (realcons). I am going to use a Python environment to take advantage of its very rich statsmodels library, a source of great options for VAR implementation with a lot of flexibility. The dataset for the demo is also coming from this API.
So the goal of this exercise is to make a 5 time-steps ahead prediction of realgdp and realcons into the future.

If you haven’t heard about panel data before you are not alone. But I’m sure you have seen this kind of data before, you just didn’t know that there’s a name for it. Here’s a formal definition of panel data:
A panel data is a multi-dimensional data of an observation that is measured repeatedly over time.
In a nutshell, a panel data is repeated observation of the same objects or individuals. Check out the following imaginary data below which might be more intuitive than reading a definition:

The purpose of this article was to demonstrate the value of two powerful multivariate forecasting techniques — Vector Autoregressive and Panel Data Models — in real-world applications. Why multivariate forecasting? Because univariate forecasting has limitations of its own. It’s a simplistic assumption to make that the future is solely dependent on the past.
The purpose of building models is to recreate and mimic the real world. The real world is complex and interconnected, so this needs to be reflected in our models.
